Replies.Reply: Just a boy, that's all.
Me.
I paid.
You was at the church with your wife and baby.
You like rabbit?
You boys been coming out here to throw rocks through my window for 20-30 years.
What's your name again?
Well, if I need you -- I know where you are.
Pretty good prayer. Mighta been wrong about that preacher.
Mornin', sir.
Pardon? I'm uh, Reverend Gus Horton, sir, how you doing?
Uh, well, Mr. Wiley Starke has passed on, sir. His funeral is tomorrow and I thought you might want to know since..
Just got old, sir.
Mr. Starke told me that you and him ran away from home when you were 6 years old. Is that true?
Well.. anyway.. I.. alright..
Buddy?
Oh! Hello..
What can I do for you, sir?
It's alright, have a seat.
What's on your mind, sir?
Get what?
For who?
For you?
You want to buy a funeral for you?
No, yes, I'm sorry. Are you sick sir?
True, but..
All right, I see. Well the church can help you get your affairs in order, arrange a service..
About what?
A eulogy? I.. don't know. What do you want me to say?
Well. I uh, I don't know much about you, Mr. Bush. I mean, I've heard stories but..
Just stories..
.you know, people talking.
Sir.. my mother used to say that gossip is the devil's radio..
.not that she didn't play that radio at full volume now and then, bless her heart, but..
.what matters when you come to the end of your life is that you're ready for the next one. Have you made peace with God, sir?
Well.. you can't buy forgiveness, Mr. Bush. It's free. But you do have to ask for it.
That was, uh, different.
My mother probably told you some of them.
"The Lord loves a cheerful giver.."
Took out ads in a bunch of papers too, something about a party?
It's that big wad of money of his you're after.
He came to see me, wanting a funeral, had a big old greasy ball of money. Talked like he thought he could buy his way to heaven with it.
Language..
I already know way more about people than I need to.
Amen.
You kind of hate to admit it when it comes to Carl but he's got a point. You don't know what Bush is doing. What if he just wants to get everybody in one place so he can turn his shotgun on them?
I looked in his eyes. The truth is nobody knows what he's capable of.
Carl said Ray paid them to set the fire. Paid them to break into the funeral home too.
Spend his money on lawyers now. You know how thrifty they are.
Can we get a ride our car's about 2 miles down the road.
Hard life if you can't read..
Don't need saving, preacher.
What got him?
Yeah, well..
I talked him into it.
Well hell..
Always thought you'd go first..
Ahh, don't look so disappointed.
You better not.
And coffee when we get there.
I can wait.
Bout time for me to get low.
Down to business Bush reaches into his overalls and puts a balled-up wad of MONEY on the pew. Horton's eyes bulge.
Need a funeral.
Me.
Am I not talking right?
Everybody dies.
I don't take care of my bones it won't get done, will it?
What would you say?
Say what you'd say right now to my face.
What stories?
What kind of stories? Say one.
Nothing in this world is free, preacher.
Want to see in my house, do you?
How's it look?
What the hell you doing here?
What?
Funeral?
Yes sir. I work at uh.. I work at..
.Quinn Funeral Home. I thought I could help you.
Sit down.

It's how you put things together, see? Some things go, some things never will. Indians said that everything spoke to them. That's how they made medicine and knew what to eat. Things talked to them clear as we talk. You believe that?
If you don't listen you won't hear nothing.
Magic.
What'd everybody say about what happened in town?
That crazy old son of a bitch tried to beat a man to death for no reason? That it?
People say that. But they don't mean it. They think what they think and they don't want to know anything else.
Like life after dying. Heaven.
Ya'll know lots of stories about me?
Tell one.
I rather you did.
Is that all?
Leave it.
You from anywhere?
I'm after a funeral.
Forget the box. What else?
No.
Got it.
Party.
A party.
Funeral party.
And I want to be there.
I want to be there now.
Yes or no?
Sit down.
I want everybody to come who's got a story to tell about me.
Then I want 4 counties worth of people at the party.
Hey Mattie.
Heard you moved off.
Well.
You look like you always did.
What for?
How much is it gonna cost?
It moves, don't it?
Fancy car for the dead.
Don't leave me naked.
Why you want my picture made?
And you want me to look like this?
Why?
So a crazy old nutter draws more.
Do you ever say what you mean?
He's paying.
What do you think?
Maybe the Devil won't either. Might work out.
Where's the shoes?
Don't wear none.
She's a peach.
We had a go.
I am.
I dreamed it.
Why would I make that up?
I got pruned.
Like what?
You come and tell yours.
40 some years.
First 38 are the hardest.
Come to the funeral and maybe you'll find out.
One more thing, boy.
Gonna be a drawing.
of the funeral we draw names. Then when I die, the winner gets my place, 300 acres of timber that hasn't been touched in 40 years.
Send it to the Quinn Funeral Home.
Buy a ticket, son.
Mattie?
Wasn't nowhere else to go.
Well.
I reckon so.
You want to see it?
You always know where you stand with a dog. Want to lay here with them someday if they'll have me.
You leave things alone, they know what to do.
No, Ma'am. I don't know what to do about anything much.
Some people are more suited to it than others, I reckon.
How you sleeping these days, girl?
You sleep good?
Chamomile, it's good when the nights get long. Helps you nod off.
You still play the piano?
I got a good feeling when you played. Remember that time you was playing and the lamp burned out?
What?
Well. I heard you married.
You have a tender heart, always did.
You can't wait for anything, Mattie. Close your eyes, hold your breath.. stay in one spot your whole life, but you're still moving, like the world's moving under you. There's no waiting.
Reckon not, Little Bit.
What do you think, boy?
Can I trust you?
Not what I asked.
Hush.
They goddamn..

Take out for the expenses you've already had and give me the receipts. As the bills come in for things, give them to me and I'll pay them. Put this money in a box and the boy and I'll take it someplace in the morning. Whatever new comes in, keep it in the bottom of one of them ugly caskets in there 'till I come get it. After the party, name a fair price for what you've done and we'll settle up.
I'll be at the car.
North.
Till I say, son.
Don't say nothing.
You can say "hi".
Hey, Charlie.
Still standing.
That's Buddy Robinson, he don't talk much.
Yes, sir.
Well.
Whatever you want to, Charlie.
Sit still.
He can hear what's said.
I did.. what I thought was right.
You self-righteous..
I built my own jail and put myself in it! And I stayed in it for 40 goddamn years! No wife, no kids, no friends! That's not enough?
Well. Why don't you come and say that then, Charlie? Hell, say it all! I don't care.
Do you have to?

There's a whole lot of things that you don't know. Like what a dog dreams. You can make up a story about him chasing rabbits but you don't know if there's rabbits in there or not. And he can't tell you, can he?
People don't say what they mean either so you don't really know any more about them then you do about that dog's dream.
That time you left my house I saw you stop and look back. You wanted to know what could make somebody like me.
Well here you are, son, here you are.
Well, I... I ain't stayed with nobody in a.. in a long while.
Let me out.
Stop the car.
Put the money in a casket.
Get the hell out of here, boy!
They keep talking about forgiveness.. ask Jesus for forgiveness.. I never did nothing to Him..
Please, Ma'am.
Thank you.
Can I sit a minute?
You want to know why I have your sister's picture on my wall?
Can you help who you love?
I've had 40 years to think about it and I still don't know.
I want to tell you how it was. If you don't want me to, I'll go.
I came to see you and she was there, hanging clothes on the line with your mama.
She turned around..
.and.. I promise you that I did not know that I had a heart till right then.
You were a fine fine girl. I didn't know why you wanted anything to do with me but I was gonna keep coming to see you 'till my luck ran out.
And then I saw her.
It's still going on, Little Bit.
Been there.
They get it?
Is he all right?
You sure?
They get the whiskey?
Don't know.
Don't know that I'm doing it.
Thinking to call it off.
Damn well can if I want to.
If I say no, it's no. Send the money back.
I care about this town as much as they care about me.

It was the end of the line, tell it all, get out of jail party. But I guess I ain't got the goddamn guts to open my own mouth and I can't get nobody to talk for me so the hell with it. And to hell with me.
Getting a suntan.
You have no goddamn idea how right you are, son.
I'll sit here a minute.
We're a pair, ain't we?
Just going through the motions.
There's Alive and there's Dead.
Sonsabitches.
You figure he took off with it?
Well.. what do you want to do?
Hell. Do it if you can.
I guess for everyone like me, there's one like you, son. I about forgot that.
Why did you change your mind?
Thank you.
I don't.
I'm gonna try and tell it, Charlie, I really am. But if I can't get it done, would you do it? I want it said. Please, sir.
Tell'em the box is in the barn.
You asked for it you old ornery sonofabitch, now what are you gonna do?
Sonsabitches.
Go on, I'll paint the porch with his head.
Now pick up them cans and keep pouring.
You heard me.
Pour it on your head. All of it.
Pour it or die, I don't care which.
I got two barrels, anybody else wants to rabbit, now's the time.
A second chance is a precious thing, son. Don't waste it.
Tried to burn me out. Let the boy be, he didn't mean nothing.
Close the door.
Boil some water and I'll tell you how to make me a poultice.
Don't sugar coat it.
Let's go 'fore I lose my nerve.
You ain't nervous? All them white folks out there?
Stick with me, you'll be all right.
Pretty interesting day so far, huh boy?
Thank you, Charlie. Thank you.
Had to go clear to Illinois to find somebody that had anything good to say about me. Hell of a thing.
I'm not a smart man or a wise one.
I fell in love with a married lady.
Her husband answered the door.
He had blood on him.
I hit him pretty hard, knocked him down. Can't remember going upstairs but I remember I saw a hammer on the steps and it had blood and hair on it.
I found her in the bedroom. She was crawling across the floor.

But before I could get to her and help her up.. a kerosene lamp hit the wall. And then her husband jumped on my back. Funny what happens sometimes when things go wrong. It's like the clock stops and you have all the time in the world to think. I could see that her husband had set the downstairs on fire before he came up.
And as I was slamming his head into the wall, trying to get shed of him, I could see clear as anything that it was all my fault. If I'd just never spoke to her..
And as I was thinking about that, I saw that the lamp he threw had set the room we were in on fire too.
And then I realized that I was on fire. I tried to put myself out but I couldn't, everything was..
I dropped him, turned around and saw her lying on the floor and called her name. She looked up at me..
.and the next thing I knew, I was flying..
I don't know how I got out the window.
No matter how many times I play it in my mind, I can't remember jumping. I thought I killed him, but maybe he pushed me, I don't know...
I swear to you, if I left her in there.. everything I know about myself is a lie. But that don't matter.
I didn't get her out, Little Bit, I didn't. I'm sorry.
Wonder if her hair would be white?
Just fair, son.
What's his name?
He ain't gonna throw rocks at me, is he?
You boys did good. Real good.
Bring my shirt back, I just got it broke in.
Thanks again for coming, Charlie.
Did you ever get my bill?
Look at that. My funeral and everybody's in there but me.
I heard such awful things about him when I was a kid.
It's none of our business.
Get out of here.
I hope not.
Are you serious?
Good Lord, you had a crush on him!
I didn't hear him wake up.
Everything's all right, hon.
Is that right?
You boys..
You already have.
About Mr. Bush?
So why aren't you happy about it?
Is it what he wants?
You are not responsible for what other people do, Buddy, just you.
At least I am when I'm half naked.
I'm not mad. I'm concerned She shoves the skillet off the burner and comes to him.
If I could get my hands on whoever did this, you'd see mad.
You want eggs, Frank, or will the skillet do?
What's wrong? My husband has his head bashed in and all you care about is this party!
This is not how family acts!
She wouldn't come. I don't..
What are you doing, son?
Empty those cans in your daddy's truck and get back in here. Now.
Stop it!! Get away!
Look at that. A mule drinking coffee!
Hey, hey, where you going? He said the woods..
Finally found somebody that likes Bonnie's coffee.
Hey..
I'm talking to you..
We know about you. You stay out of this diner. There's women and children here and we don't want you around them.
You better hear me. I see you here again, I'll.. Hey! Hey!
Shit..
I'll kill him!
What were you doing with that old bastard in town today, anyway?
What the hell is a funeral party?
I'll tell you one damn thing, ain't nobody gonna go to a funeral for that son of a bitch.
Say what you want but if there hadn't been anybody there the other day he would've killed me. And I guarantee you it wouldn't have been his first time.
I made a mistake. But there's a line.. and he crossed it.. and everybody knows that too. Ya'll go on and have a party with the devil for his money but I'll dance on his grave someday.
Closer.
Don't do it!
What?
Don't hurt him! It's my fault.
Help him, Gus, please..
Ya'll better hush, that's old Bush.
Daddy!
Frank?
There was a fight. It was..
Well yeah but this time it was with that old man Bush.
No, the old man did the beating.
What?
Well..
We get it done down here, we're just not in a hurry about it.
I might know someone who is looking for a funeral.
It was all wadded up.
There it is..
What are you doing?
But..
I'd feel better if you'd go too.
Hello?
Oh, Katie..
Yes, sir.
I can't remember.
Oh yeah, I heard.. you wanted a funeral.
What?
I.. I don't know, sir.
Did you make this furniture, sir?
Alright. Well. Sir, if you do want to plan for a funeral service, which I hope will be a long long time away, we'd treat you with respect and offer a good..
I don't..
There's two sides to every story.
Yes, sir, but I think people are so scared of what they don't know that they make things up to feel better about it.
I hope that part's true, don't you?
But I don't think we know the actual truth about much of anything. I know I don't. I'm just guessing most of the time.
Lord, that's good..
I never..
Yes, sir, I guess, but..
I'd rather not.
Well. When I was kid I heard you killed some men in a fist fight.
Buddy Robinson, sir.
Would you like to come in, sir?
Frank Quinn, Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush is an amazing carpenter.
What kind of party?
You want to be at your funeral..
Pretty big detail.
That probably covers 4 counties..
Like what?
What?
But..
But..
Seeing it is better than hearing about it.
We say that funerals are "For the Living" but we forget what that means sometimes, I guess.

I was thinking about your funeral party before I went to sleep last night and I think I understand it a little now. When I was a kid, my folks where killed in a bad car wreck and the people at the funeral home... they did the impossible as far as I was concerned. I don't know what I would've done without them. And I remember wishing that my mother and daddy were there to see how beautiful they made everything.
That's what we're trying to tell you. We're gonna run an ad in some papers about your party and put up posters of you.
It's how people recognize you, sir.
Damn. You look pretty good..
I wouldn't know you, sir.
He didn't.
I'm glad you don't know how quick it can change.
You're betting on a man dying..
Yeah! But, but it's not our money.
He should be here. I'm gonna go get him.
Money makes people do funny things.
I think you should probably put it in the bank, sir.
Mr. Bush, I didn't mean to imply..
I don't know who's selling who what anymore.
Not only that but something feels really wrong.
Yeah, but..
A piece?
But..
I'm lost again.
All right.
Thank you.
I might have a crying fit coming on too.
Feeling a little weepy.
I can maybe do something really good for us, Katy.
I mean, money wise.
Yeah. I'm getting half of whatever we make off of him.
Didn't know I wasn't.
I was happy for a minute. And then the whole thing of making a carnival out of a person's death, I don't know if it's right.
He says it is.
You're right. You're always right.
Right.
Where to, sir?
How far?
How much further now?
To who?
Hi.
Hi.
Hi!
Almost nothing, sir. I just work at the funeral home.
No?!
How's a man like him make something like this? I mean, I know he's a good carpenter but this is..
What ya'll were talking about..
Are you coming to the funeral?
Can I ask you something?
Yes. What are we doing? Since the day you came into the funeral home, I don't think anything has happened that you didn't want to happen. I just don't know where it's going.
Not unless he's a very special dog.
But what..?
I better stop and tell Frank we're back. He's probably had 2 or 3 hissy fits by now.
Why don't you stay the night at the house and I'll take you home in the morning?
It's fine if you want to.
What?
You can't walk. It's too far..
You might as well get back in, I'll follow you all the way.
Not responsible. Not responsible.
Frank? Hello? Mr. Bush?
No. I was putting the money in..
Mattie sits beside a fire, knitting a baby blanket by an oil lamp. All at once the lights sputter on, the radio lights up, warms, and begins to PLAY, as a KNOCK at the door..
I see you're mad.
No, you're mad.
What's the matter?
What?
I told you, we went up to Illinois and met a preacher.
He asked the preacher to come to the funeral. He said no.
It won't do you any good.
He knows something about Bush, something bad, I think.
Wouldn't say but..
Stay out of her way today, partner.
What are you doing, sir?
Are you stuck?
Are you sick?
What does that mean?
No, sir.
It doesn't matter. Listen. Frank went somewhere and the raffle money is gone.
I don't know. I don't want to think that. But the money's not here and I don't know where it is. He said he'd call and he never did.
I don't..
I want to make this funeral for you if you want it.
I'm glad you decided to come, sir.
Did you take the money out of the casket?
Why didn't you tell me?!
You forgot?! Where is it?
I forgot to tell you, Mr. Bush already said he would do it.
Where's Mattie?
Are you alright, sir?!
Why don't you sit down, sir?
Are you sure?
How you doing, sir?
Larry, Lawrence, after my dad, sir.
Not if knows what's good for him.
We don't have to do that now. You get some rest.
The day of the party he told me about the will he had in the secret drawer of his table. He left the raffle money to all of us.
But you have to pay for Mule's upkeep for the rest of his life.
And he set up a fund for the upkeep of your church.
No catch, sir.
Maybe he just knew you'd go crazy wondering what it was.
.let me guess. Hmm. Carl?
Old man?
Is there a body?
Social event of the year and I missed it.
Read the paper today?
Something strange is happening in the world right now.
People are dying in bunches.
Everywhere. But here.

I wonder what the odds are of a funeral home going broke? I mean you have a business everybody on earth needs, you can't make that work, it's got to be you right? And yet.. I don't know.. what do you do when people won't die?
Onethingabout Chicago, people knowhowto die; they drown, get runover,shot, whatever it takes.
It's them or us.
How much did he have?
Ooo, hermit money. That's good.
You've been wanting a shot at sales..
As of right now, you're on commission.
Remember; foot in the door, establish trust, and drop the hammer.
No doubt but if you don't do this by yourself, you won't know if you're any good. And you'll never be any good if you don't know you are. Go get him!
Oh yes Ma'am, I do respect your wishes but you see..
.state law requires.. No ma'am, we can't bury him under the house..
Well just for argument's sake, Ma'am, how would we get the casket under the house? No casket?
But you have to have a container of some kind, Ma'am for decency and uh, sanitation.
Yes, Ma'am, but there's lots of natural things that aren't decent.
He did what?! Good God. No, Ma'am, I didn't know that about your husband. Well, yeah now I understand why you want him under the house but still..
Come in, come in, pleasure. Coffee?
A little bit of everywhere, I guess. Get him a chair, Buddy!
How can we help you, sir?
Boy, are you in luck.
Follow me.
Solid pecan, steel handles..
Whatever you want, flowers..
Burial plot..
A service?
A what?
We can do that.
You will be, I guarantee it.
Hold on now, it's a detail, we can look at it.
So you'd like to have a funeral party while you're alive so you can go?
Yes.
Buddy, get some paper. We need to make of list of who Mr. Bush wants to invite..
Say again.
Well, sir, the thing is, how would you get people to come and tell stories about you that I'm guessing might get them, you know.. shot?
You know what, you go ahead, don't worry about it, we'll think of something. A couple of ideas just came to me.
How would she know him?
So? We got to know.
See the size of that thing?
What do you mean, what? Goddamn ball of money! He wants a party with pink balloons on his ears, we're gonna give it to him.
I sold 26 of the ugliest cars ever made one December, in Chicago, with wind blowing so hard up my ass I was farting snow flakes in July so don't tell me we can't do this.
That's the last "but" I want to hear out of you. You're a salesman now, sell!
She called him Felix.
We have a plan. All we need is a little bit of your time.
Did you say anything about money?
I didn't say anything about money.
If we can't get you what you want you don't owe us anything.
This is nothing.
Didn't buy it for them.
Where's he going?
I wish you wouldn't do that yet.
Mr. Bush, you can get all the hairs cut you want after we take your picture, I'll pay for it.
Yes.
Why?
And you want as many people to come as possible so..
Basically. Don't you think?
Take it.
I'd go see that.
Son of a bitch, it's almost worth it.
Well, normally people don't wear shoes in a casket so..
.what are you, about a 10D?
Pretty optimistic taking a change of clothes to the grave.
How you set for underwear?
One question too many.
I don't mean to be nosey but uh..
If He is, the Divine's cheating.
Don't agree with me Ray, it makes me doubt myself.
You made my point and don't even know it.
God, I love small towns.
"Felix" Bush.
A funeral party.
Hey, the man wants to be at his own funeral. What can I say? I'd like to be at my funeral so I could tell my ex-wife to kiss my..
Because, Dear, vultures are constitutionally unable to ignore the dead.
They might. He's inviting everyone who has a story about him to come.
Wouldn't you like to know what everybody says about you behind your back, Ray?
Yeah, probably not.
Let's play some cards.
It's who has it last that counts.
I got an idea. Let's try something different.
The cards in your sock? Leave'em there.
You really think you're that good that nobody sees?
You cheat at everything you do.
Am I? Then stand up and roll down your socks.
Stand up or I'll stand you up.
I'll walk you home.
You sure?
You're not going to play anymore, are you?
I'm sorry about the..we don't always fight, okay, we do, but he's had that coming for..
You came because you don't know what to do with yourself.
I slept on the same side of the bed my whole life, right? But after my wife left me, I switched sides, just like that, and never been able to go back.
I could almost kiss you on the mouth!
Hey, it's his idea!
It's what you want, right?
Jesus, kid!
Well yeah, no, but some of it's gonna be! We're putting this thing on!

I don't know exactly how much your land's worth but looks to me like you could get maybe 10 times that or more. I don't know what to do with it. I mean it's yours to do with what you want but I'm getting a little nervous about it. Never thought I'd see enough money to make me nervous. We should probably talk about the price for everything, the clothes, the ads, the food and drink for the party, the music.. our fee for everything, we'll be fair about that, I'm not worried about it.
No! Ray is not..
I mean, if it was my money I'd put it in a bank out of town so everyone didn't know my business.
Every name, every dollar, is right there!
I've done a hell of a job for you.

I've sold horses, cars, houses, hell, pocket watches pinned to the inside of my coat. I'm not ashamed of it. I don't rob banks, don't cheat at cards, and I sleep all right the nights I sleep. What was the question..?
Is it just me or is he extremely fucking articulate when he wants to be?
It's not clear, is it?
Hold on. I told you that you were working on commission..
So whatever our end of this is, you get a piece.
Half. It could help set you up, Buddy. So whatever feels wrong is gonna feel right pretty damn quick,okay? We just have to close it out. From here on, watch me, do what I do, and we'll be fine.
He wants you to go with him to take this money somewhere which means that it's you he trusts. And that's fine because I trust you too. Just don't trust him, okay?
Look, that funny feeling you have..
But the critical time is just before it closes. It's like a witching hour and everything tries to come apart. We're not going to let that happen.
Now go.
You know.. I always wondered why you wanted to work here. I thought you could do a lot better.
I didn't know about your folks, I'm really sorry.
Hey Mattie.
Was that you? It was really..
Yeah, sorry.
Uh, yeah.. Help!
Oh, okay, I just..
Where are you..?
The cut's not bad but how's the head? He moves his finger across Buddy's eyes.
Follow it.
You'll be okay. Did you see who it was?
You did good.
What the hell?!
No. Buddy sealed it up in a casket.
Yeah.
I was an army medic. He'll be fine.
But you ought to take those clothes back and get something in your size.
Brought the money back, huh?
Listen, I've been thinking.. What if we had the party at your place?
Well, think about it, we could..
What?!
You can't!
No no no, it's in motion!
You're killing me! I bought things, hired people.. promised money, everybody in town is hoping to..
It's what you said you wanted and I've busted my ass for you. So why don't you want it anymore? You owe me that.
Buddy! You up?!
Trouble.
Bush is pulling out.
What happened yesterday?
But what happened?
Son of a bitch, that's got to be..
Sorry.
Sorry. Where's the preacher?
Why not?
What is it?
Well if Bush wants him, by God, Bush is gonna get him.
What? What's wrong?
It's not like that, Katie, this is for all of us. You're like.. family to me.. I..
Well, I'm sorry. I've never had any practice.
Reverend Jackson?
Frank Quinn, Quinn funeral home.
Bush? No, sir.
Pretty sure.
You told Bush that you wouldn't come to the funeral?
To help you rethink it.
Have you rethought it?
So there is a need.
First off, Bush doesn't know I'm here.
He came to see me after he'd been here, wants to call the party off.

Said he'd meant it to be a.. end of the line, tell it all, get out of jail funeral but that he didn't have the guts to open his mouth and he couldn't get anybody to talk for him. You know anything about that part?
At first he said he wanted everybody to come who had a story about him. But he didn't want to hear their bullshit stories, did he? Pardon my language. He wants to tell one, doesn't he?
Or can't.
At least he wants the truth to come out, give him that.
Is there a boarding house around here?
Yeah but if you're not coming, I'm not going back. I made promises I can't keep to people I care about.
Yeah.
I forgot.
In the hearse, under the floorboards.
What? Nobody steals a hearse. Now all we got to do is take the Reverend here to Bush and..
You're shittin' me?!
You can't leave you just got here.
Hold on..
Honestly? We don't have a clue about what's going to happen here.
Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I'm Frank Quinn of Quinn Funeral Home. Welcome to the live funeral party of Mr. Felix Bush!
I've done some things in my life, but never this. Bet you haven't either, bet no one has.
We try to make things predictable and safe but if we don't risk everything to get what we want, we don't want it enough.
The person who made all of this happen for us doesn't like the spotlight but Buddy Robinson is the heart of Quinn Funeral Home and I'm proud to know him.
I know many of you have heard stories about Mr. Bush. But today I've been told that we're going to hear another kind of story, his.
Missed the bone. Got any alcohol and clean rags?
This is gonna hurt.
Can't stop pulling Aces out of his ass, can he?
Yeah. We'll come out tomorrow.
Are you alright, Mattie?
What?!
Felix?!
Felix! Say hello to me!
I've been back a while.
How are you?
A thousand years ago he was the most interesting man I'd ever met.
He was. And I don't mean just the way he looked.
Oh no, listen, he was beautiful.

Most people are just laid out nice and simple, you know? You always know what they're thinking and where you are with them. But he was this.. big old cave that went deeper and deeper. You'd never get to the end of him.
All the girls did. I know he's something wild that crawls out of the hills once in a while and gets into trouble now but there's still nobody like him.
Oh please.. you think the Lord's taking sides in a poker game in a funeral home?
Jesus, would you two stop it!
Who are you talking about?
You're giving him a party?
Whatever you're drinking is not being good to you at all.
What makes you think she'd show up for you?
Felix has money?
Is he sick, Gus?
Or want to.
Everybody knows you started it.
Don't look at me like that. I remember when you were born. You were the sweetest little boy. What is wrong with you?
He wouldn't..
No. Thank you.
Oh, I don't know. Thank you for inviting me though.
When someone you love is gone, you can pour everything, even a lifetime of things into the place where they were but it's still always empty.
'Night.
Good Lord. Have you completely lost your mind?
Felix?
Look at you. I wondered if you were still under that beard.
I heard you on the radio.
You've gotten downright chatty.
This is nice. I drove by a few times after I got back but..
Do you want me to?
It really is beautiful. Probably looked like this everywhere a hundred years ago.
Like you?
You've been alone a long time.
That's funny cause I never thought that it'd suit you. I knew you wouldn't be like anybody else but..
How am I what?
No, not lately. How'd you know?
You always were good with your hands.
I teach a few girls.
Sure is quiet out here.
I said it's..
He was a Doctor; a real good man.
The list of people who are gone is getting longer and longer and sometimes I feel like all I'm doing is waiting for my name to come up.
And there's no getting over some things either, is there?
Little Bit?! Oh my God, nobody's called me that in..
This is a surprise.
Was there something you..?
What?
I'm sorry, I have lessons all afternoon. I have to get back in.
Sorry.
What are you doing here?
I'm not stupid, Felix. No, I take that back. How long was it going on? She was already married when I met you. Were you just making up to me to get to her?
If you're not going to talk, leave.
I don't know either, so..
Don't lie to me. When did you take up with her?
She was married! And she wasn't just my sister, she was my best friend. We told each other everything. I can't.. how long did it go on?!
How long?
Did you have anything to do with her death?
Tell me.
Felix!
Get out of my house! NOW!
And go to hell!
You need to see a doctor..
Just tell me, Felix. Did you hurt Mary or not?
Fool, it's too late for bulbs..
.too goddamn late..
Oh, Felix..
Oh, I don't know. I'm still moving, I guess..
Exactly.
I would have turned down your loan if you were my own dear mother, Frank.
Oh yes. Buying him clothes, getting him a haircut..on credit.
That hermit, what's his name..
What money is that?
How much has he got? Maybe he can.
Old man is going to ride the Weird Train right into the ground, isn't he?
Oh for God's sake, face it Frank, you're broke.
Please. I've won that 4 times already.
Go ahead and lay your watch down, Frank. But I am going to keep it this time, alright, on principle.
What are you trying to pull now?
Sees what?
You are a pathetic man. And a goddamn..

Friends, we have a treat for you today on WCGM. Our special guest is going to tell us about an event that everyone is talking about. And here he is, Mr. Felix Bush, the mysterious hermit of Caleb County!
So tell us, sir, exactly how did you come up with the idea of having a funeral party before you die?
Really?
Okay. Now I have to say that you don't look quite like you do on the posters.
Well, you're a bit of a local legend, sir. I was a little nervous about our interview. I've heard some pretty wild stories..
Well uh, just.. from what I understand, you want everyone who has a story about you to come and tell it. Is that right?
Thank you. Now how long have you been living out there by yourself?
40 years with nobody to talk to?
But why would you do that, Mr.
What kind of drawing, sir?
For 5 dollars?
You heard him! If you want a chance to win 300 acres of virgin timber worth thousands and thousands of dollars, send 5 dollars along with your name and address to..
Frank Quinn at Quinn Funeral Home.
Replies.Didascalie: (off Frank waving and pointing to himself)

Replies.Reply: I'll take a ticket.
I didn't mean it like..
Folks, I've just received word of a tragic turn of events at the Bush Funeral Party. It seems that Mr.
When I know more I will let you know. I'm sure he would appreciate your prayers..
Hello.
Are you sure you're in the right place? Not expecting a funeral.
Felix?!
Yes.
Reverend Charlie Jackson.
Someone better talk. A ghost pulls up in the driveway in a hearse, you expect a little bit of a story.
My hearing is not what it was. It sounded like you said you want me to preach at your funeral party with you sitting there?
You know I've talked to God a lot about you over the years and he said he broke the mould when he made you. Said you were sure entertaining to watch but way too much trouble.
What would you want me to say at this funeral?
Could you give us a minute?
What's the matter? You scared to be alone with me?
All right. After you left here..
You confessed? Asked forgiveness?
Did you tell her, Felix?
You came a long way for nothing then.
Don't you dare..
You know it isn't.
Not on your life.
How much do you know about him?
Do you know he built this church?
Magic?
Maybe it's the best of him, maybe he put his soul into it, I don't know.
For him and God to know I guess. I wish I'd never been put between them, that's for sure.
I will tell you that he showed up here half dead. I had just started preaching. Over the next 4 years we built this.
How'd you find me?
I was going to play some dominos this afternoon. But something told me to stay home. I should have played dominos. Is he out there?
You sure?
Did you check the back?
If he got that, why are you here?
I don't need any help.
I wouldn't be so sure about that.
He's got a way of making people do what he wants them to.
Is he really a hermit?
I don't care.
About time.
Because he won't.
Or won't.
I'll think about it.
I said I'd think.
Free will is not all that it's cracked up to be.
Where can I catch a train?
Watch and learn.
Where's the station?
Expecting a crowd?
Pretty nice jail.
How do you want to do this?
Why don't you lay down, Felix?
There's white folks here?!
You're the one they're shooting at.
I'm Reverend Charlie Jackson. Felix wants to continue with his funeral.
We like to imagine that good and bad, right and wrong, are miles apart. But the truth is, very often they're..
.all tangled up with each other.
Replies.Didascalie: (brings his hand together and laces his fingers  TIGHTLY)

Replies.Reply: Some 40 years ago Felix Bush dropped into my life and then dropped out. In between he built the most beautiful sanctuary that I've ever seen. A lot of wonderful things happened in that church.
I'm proud of you.
Thank you for my church.
Well, Felix, this one's for real, I guess. I didn't actually see them put you in the box so..

Wherever you are, you're probably giving someone a hard time or something wonderful and priceless just to confuse them. Not everything can be figured out, nor everybody. I wish you peace from the burdens of your mind and heart.
I told you. Nobody listens to the preacher.
What's the catch?
Still don't get it, do you? With Felix, there's always a catch.
Whatever he did, it's been locked up in him for 40 years and he can't get it out.
I think he told you. You may be the only person he told. And now he wants you to tell it for him.
He's crazy!
Holy Mother of..

Lord, you say you move in mysterious ways and we believe you because we don't understand much of anything. And so we come to you today not seeking answers to what's happened here but asking you to help us open our hearts a little more to each other and find some forgiveness and understanding.
